faster-growing divisions such as YouTube.', 'That extra clarity sparked a surge in Alphabet shares.', 'Facebook is in a similar position.', 'With waning adoption of its core apps and a new focus on the metaverse, the company is eager to focus on its growth prospects.', "However, the results on Wednesday show the new Reality Labs division isn't growing fast enough yet.", 'The group also reported an operating loss of more than $10 billion for 2021, more than 4 times its revenue.', '"I\'m encouraged by the progress we made this past year in a number of important growth areas like Reels, commerce, and virtual reality, and we\'ll continue investing in these and other key priorities in 2022 as we work towards building the metaverse," CEO Mark Zuckerberg said in a statement on Wednesday.', 'Are you a Facebook, Twitter, or Snap employee with insight to share?', 'Got a tip?', 'Contact Kali Hays at khays@insider.com or through secure messaging app Signal at 949-280-0267.', 'Reach out using a non-work device.', 'Twitter DM at @hayskali.', "Check out Insider's source guide for other suggestions on how to share information securely."]
key_sentences: Facebook's metaverse business reported disappointing results for the first time on Wednesday, showing the company's effort to build a new computing platform is still some way from taking off. Reality Labs, the division developing the AR and VR technology required for a metaverse, generated $877 million in revenue in the fourth quarter of 2021, a 22% increase from the same period in 2020. Sales for the whole of last year came in at $2.27 billion, Facebook said. Analysts told Insider last week they expected annual revenue of close to $3 billion from Reality Labs. Wall Street took Facebook's results badly on Wednesday, sending the stock down 18% in after-hours trading. Facebook's renaming of its corporate entity to Meta and moving to break out a segment that is far from profitable but new and growing is a page out of Google's playbook. Facebook is in a similar position. With waning adoption of its core apps and a new focus on the metaverse, the company is eager to focus on its growth prospects. However, the results on Wednesday show the new Reality Labs division isn't growing fast enough yet. "I'm encouraged by the progress we made this past year in a number of important growth areas like Reels, commerce, and virtual reality, and we'll continue investing in these and other key priorities in 2022 as we work towards building the metaverse," CEO Mark Zuckerberg said in a statement on Wednesday. Are you a Facebook, Twitter, or Snap employee with insight to share?

label: META
title: Jack Dorsey told MicroStrategy's Michael Saylor that Facebook should have focused on bitcoin instead of wasting time on diem
article: ['In his first interview for some time, Square chief executive Jack Dorsey said Facebook should have spent more time focussing on making bitcoin accessible to its users, rather than on its own stablecoin project.', 'Facebook, now known as Meta, has ditched its diem stablecoin project and is in the process of selling off assets.', 'The project launched back in 2019 under the name "libra", but failed to take off, even after a rebranding exercise, due to regulatory issues.', '"This whole thing with libra and then diem, I think there\'s a ton of lessons there.', 'Hopefully they learned a lot, but I think there was a lot of wasted effort and time," Dorsey told Michael Saylor on Tuesday at MicroStrategy\'s "Bitcoin for Corporations 2022" conference, he spoke\n\nIn particular, the Block CEO said he felt the time spent on the diem project would have been better served working on bitcoin and improving access.', '"Those two or three years or however long it\'s been could\'ve been spent making bitcoin more accessible for more people around the world," he said.', 'This is one issue bitcoin faces at the moment which needs addressing, according to Dorsey.', 'He said to improve this, there needs to be more focus on bitcoin from companies like Facebook.', "He said he also believed that this had been Facebook's original plan with libra.", '"We have this open network right now.', "And it's usable.", "It's not accessible to everyone, but it's usable.", "The easier we make it, the faster we make it, the more approachable we make it, it's going to better everything.", 'Including everything Facebook intended to do with libra," Dorsey said.', 'Since the announcement of his departure from Twitter in November, Dorsey has gone ever deeper into the crypto world, even renaming his Square payments company, which facilitates bitcoin purchases through Cash App, to Block.', 'Block has been feverishly signing partnerships with celebrities and sports stars to promote bitcoin.', 'In that time, Aaron Rodgers, Odel Beckham Jr. and two Golden State Warriors stars have opted to take part of their salaries in bitcoin as part of this push.', 'As well as his work on Block and his Twitter spat, Dorsey has set up a bitcoin legal defense fund with other crypto enthusiasts in order to protect and support developers building on the network.', 'Read more: Wall Street analysts have picked these 28 semiconductor chip manufacturers as stocks to buy, including 4 metaverse darlings that could offer double-digit upside']
key_sentences: In his first interview for some time, Square chief executive Jack Dorsey said Facebook should have spent more time focussing on making bitcoin accessible to its users, rather than on its own stablecoin project. Facebook, now known as Meta, has ditched its diem stablecoin project and is in the process of selling off assets. He said to improve this, there needs to be more focus on bitcoin from companies like Facebook. He said he also believed that this had been Facebook's original plan with libra. Including everything Facebook intended to do with libra," Dorsey said. Read more: Wall Street analysts have picked these 28 semiconductor chip manufacturers as stocks to buy, including 4 metaverse darlings that could offer double-digit upside

label: META
title: Check out the 10-slide pitch deck that four ex-Facebook engineers used to secure $36 million in funding for their crypto start-up from backers like Andreessen Horowitz and Coinbase
article: ['Facebook suffered another crypto setback this week as its diem digital currency project started selling its assets to repay investors.', 'And it was the delayed launch of diem that encouraged four engineers to quit Facebook and found their own crypto start-up last year.', '"Facebook\'s technology was developed, but diem wasn\'t able to launch for a number of reasons," Evan Cheng, a former director for Facebook\'s Novi digital wallet, told Insider in a recent interview.', '"Not being able to launch really weighed on the four of us, so we decided to start our own company."', 'Cheng is now chief executive of the blockchain infrastructure start-up Mysten Labs, which he founded alongside fellow ex-Facebook engineers Adeniyi Abiodun, Sam Blackshear and George Danezis.', 'All four had previously worked together on the Novi project.', "There's a significant contrast between working in Big Tech and at a crypto start-up, according to Cheng, who previously spent ten years at Apple and six-and-a-half years at Facebook.", '"In crypto, the speed of execution is completely different," he said.', '"We can\'t depend on anyone else to open doors for us anymore, so we have to move a lot faster than ever before."', "Moving fast helped Mysten secure $36 million of funding in December, with Cheng successfully pitching to investors from Andreessen Horowitz's a16z crypto fund and Coinbase's VC arm.", '"It\'s great to have investor partners that understand our vision," Cheng told Insider.', '"A16z in particular has built lots of really impressive services, which was really attractive for us."', "Mysten is building underlying technology that will help firms that aren't necessarily crypto-native to develop their blockchain capabilities, Cheng said.", 'Andreessen Horowitz invests in many such companies across its 62 funds.', '"We have some access to portfolio companies that operate outside of crypto, but might think about wanting to use blockchain technology down the road," Cheng said.', '"That was what made a16z a perfect partner in our eyes."', "Here are the 10 pitch deck slides that Mysten's founders used to secure the December funding round.", 'Some elements have been redacted due to non-disclosure agreements.']
key_sentences: Facebook suffered another crypto setback this week as its diem digital currency project started selling its assets to repay investors. And it was the delayed launch of diem that encouraged four engineers to quit Facebook and found their own crypto start-up last year. "Facebook's technology was developed, but diem wasn't able to launch for a number of reasons," Evan Cheng, a former director for Facebook's Novi digital wallet, told Insider in a recent interview. Cheng is now chief executive of the blockchain infrastructure start-up Mysten Labs, which he founded alongside fellow ex-Facebook engineers Adeniyi Abiodun, Sam Blackshear and George Danezis. There's a significant contrast between working in Big Tech and at a crypto start-up, according to Cheng, who previously spent ten years at Apple and six-and-a-half years at Facebook.

label: META
title: Facebook lost $10 billion on its metaverse investments in 2021. These 4 challenges are what experts say are standing in the way of its success.
article:
['Some version of a metaverse, a 3D internet accessed through augmented- or virtual-reality devices, seems inevitable with tech giants such as Facebook, Apple, and Microsoft investing heavily in the space.', "That's striking fear into the hearts of experts, including those in the security and legal fields, who see such a platform exacerbating existing online problems and creating new issues.", '"It's a match to a keg of gasoline," said Marc Berkman, the executive director of the nonprofit Organization for Social Media Safety.', 'Jon Sriro, a cochair of the data-privacy and cybersecurity practice at the law firm Jaffe, Raitt, Heuer & Weiss, said it made no difference whether a metaverse was controlled by a centralized entity like Facebook or was decentralized.', 'When it comes to data and security, "I see doom either way," he added.', 'A version of the internet that is as close to the physical world as possible, populated with hyperrealistic avatars partaking in endless activities with access to digital goods, is full of opportunity but also ripe for abuse.', 'Here are 4 scenarios experts are most worried about.', "Physical abuse in a virtual world

An early user of Facebook's Horizon Worlds VR experience said late last year that she was groped while other users looked on.", 'Had such an incident occurred in the physical world, it would be a crime.', 'But since it occurred in a virtual space, it was unclear what, if any, legal recourse the user had.', '"I imagine she felt so violated, and it's got to be a crime, but where do you go?"', 'Sriro said.', 'An assault like this would likely fall under the scope of federal cybercrime law, which is handled by the FBI.', 'But the laws are not up to date with the metaverse.', 'The agency already has trouble dealing with online activity such as ransomware, he added, given that malicious actors are often based in other jurisdictions.', '"We'll see an increase in concern around safety and abuse," said Michael Coates, Twitter's former chief information-security officer and the founder of Altitude Networks, a data-security firm.', '"When the online world is more distributed, you'll face the idea of who is the moderator."', 'Breach of biometric data

Breaches of personal information are common online already.', 'Companies operating a metaverse, which may require the wearing of many new types of physical tracking devices, would have access to much more than your credit-card number.', '"They'll be collecting so much data about our physical selves and cyber worlds and habits and combining it," Sriro said.', '"It will be incredible — their ability to target people and control how they react."', 'Such data would probably be valuable to advertisers and fields such as insurance and surveillance, as well as tempting for people who may be working in ransomware or doxing.', '"Doxing is bad enough now.', 'Think of what it could be with that level of information," Sriro said.', 'Fraud and theft

Fraud and theft are "inevitable" in the metaverse, given that it's a new technology that many people don't yet fully understand, Coates said.', 'Theft of digital goods in the metaverse may increase.', 'But so far, enforcement of ownership is limited or nonexistent.', '"Let's say in the metaverse you've invested thousands of dollars in digital goods and it's stolen.', 'What's your recourse?"', 'Coates said.', '"You may not have any means of recovery."', "Relatively simple web links are already being used to gain access to people's crypto wallets, and users are being duped into losing NFTs they purchased for the equivalent of tens of thousands of dollars, he said.", 'Coates was unsure of how much power a company behind a centralized metaverse would have when it came to digital goods, and he thought it was unlikely that a cohesive approach would emerge.', 'More likely, the issue of theft would be left to a "free market," in much the same way protecting a computer against computer viruses often comes down to the availability of antivirus software.', '"It will create its own ecosystem where there are best practices to protect yourself and more trusted brokers or custodians," he said.', 'Lost sense of reality

Felix Mohr, who worked in fintech before getting into Web3 businesses, including his Crypto Fight Club game, saw the immersive quality of a metaverse as one of its biggest problems.', '"People can be anyone in the metaverse and live out their wildest fantasies that they might never dare to try in real life," Mohr said.', 'Gaming is already largely designed to give players a dopamine rush that keeps them playing for hours at a stretch.', 'A metaverse would amplify the effect because a person could "build a strong emotional connection with the character they have shaped," and they could completely withdraw from the real world, Mohr explained.', "It's particularly a risk for young people, some of whom have already experienced the negative effects of social media, including bullying, eating disorders, and easier access to illegal drugs.", 'Then there are the issues of catfishing and sex trafficking, Beckman said.', '"Our working assumption is that there will be more ways to do all of this when you're in a 3D world just walking around," Berkman said.', '"Once this technology gets entrenched, it's very difficult to make systemic changes."']
key_sentences:
Some version of a metaverse, a 3D internet accessed through augmented- or virtual-reality devices, seems inevitable with tech giants such as Facebook, Apple, and Microsoft investing heavily in the space. "It's a match to a keg of gasoline," said Marc Berkman, the executive director of the nonprofit Organization for Social Media Safety. Jon Sriro, a cochair of the data-privacy and cybersecurity practice at the law firm Jaffe, Raitt, Heuer & Weiss, said it made no difference whether a metaverse was controlled by a centralized entity like Facebook or was decentralized. Physical abuse in a virtual world

An early user of Facebook's Horizon Worlds VR experience said late last year that she was groped while other users looked on. But the laws are not up to date with the metaverse. Companies operating a metaverse, which may require the wearing of many new types of physical tracking devices, would have access to much more than your credit-card number. Fraud and theft

Fraud and theft are "inevitable" in the metaverse, given that it's a new technology that many people don't yet fully understand, Coates said. Theft of digital goods in the metaverse may increase. "Let's say in the metaverse you've invested thousands of dollars in digital goods and it's stolen. Coates was unsure of how much power a company behind a centralized metaverse would have when it came to digital goods, and he thought it was unlikely that a cohesive approach would emerge. Lost sense of reality

Felix Mohr, who worked in fintech before getting into Web3 businesses, including his Crypto Fight Club game, saw the immersive quality of a metaverse as one of its biggest problems. "People can be anyone in the metaverse and live out their wildest fantasies that they might never dare to try in real life," Mohr said. A metaverse would amplify the effect because a person could "build a strong emotional connection with the character they have shaped," and they could completely withdraw from the real world, Mohr explained. It's particularly a risk for young people, some of whom have already experienced the negative effects of social media, including bullying, eating disorders, and easier access to illegal drugs.

label: GOOG
title: Leaked Microsoft research shows the market is embracing Bing and ChatGPT's potential to 'challenge Google's monopoly'
article:
['Microsoft is suddenly not boring.', "The software giant is considered to have a real chance of challenging Google's online search dominance through a partnership with OpenAI and its ChatGPT technology, according to a confidential report prepared recently for Microsoft.", 'Sprinklr, which analyzes online sentiment, studied a wide range of comments about Microsoft, its Bing search engine, ChatGPT, and Google.', 'It revealed broadly positive sentiment about a ChatGPT-Bing combination.', 'The first fruits of this partnership are due to be announced on Tuesday.', 'Microsoft found that online conversations around the Bing-ChatGPT partnership were largely positive, showing "the market welcomes a change," the study stated.', 'Many people see "ChatGPT + Bing as a 'threat' or 'challenge' to Google Search," it added.', '"Bing can leverage the power of ChatGPT for improved results and challenge Google's monopoly," the report, marked Microsoft Confidential, explained.', '"Users believe this to be a shift to 'level the playing field.'"', 'Insider obtained a copy of the report.', "A Microsoft spokesperson didn't respond to a request for comment on Monday.", 'The study ran from late November to early January, capturing data from news publications and online services including Twitter, YouTube, Instagram, and Reddit.', 'The findings suggest one reason why Microsoft is expanding its partnership with OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT, an AI-powered chatbot that has taken the world by storm since its public release in late November.', 'Earlier this month, Microsoft announced a a big new investment in OpenAI.', "The software giant is also planning to incorporate OpenAI's technology into some of its other products, like Office apps, The Information previously reported.", ''Big year for Bing'

People were particularly "excited" about Microsoft's investment in OpenAI, with some calling it a "forward thinking" move, the Sprinklr study noted.', 'They are "eagerly" awaiting more ChatGPT features in Office products, with many expressing surprise over the fast-moving partnership, it added.', 'They also "enthusiastically" mentioned that ChatGPT's integration with Office applications could "improve efficiency and productivity," while some stated they would "switch to Bing," which could "challenge Google's 'search dominance,'" according to the study.', '"As Microsoft continues to focus on building AI and machine learning offerings, integrating GPT could give Microsoft a competitive edge," the internal report said.', '"Some online expect a big year for Bing and were delighted by the 'Incredible additions to search.'"', 'Some said the ChatGPT user experience was "weird" or "scary"

Not all responses were positive.', "Most notably, some people were worried about ChatGPT's lack of fact-checking and the uncertainty around its privacy, a bigger concern for use in educational environments.", 'Some said the ChatGPT user experience was "weird" or "scary," and were skeptical of the profitability of investing in an AI research company, like OpenAI, the study found

Still, ChatGPT's "humanlike" responses were seen as a major appeal and an improvement from the current search engine's lists of links, it said.', 'The report added Microsoft can "double down on the verification of results accuracy" and should consider how this new technology "will be used by both professionals and students to complete tasks."', 'But Microsoft's excitement over its partnership with ChatGPT is best seen in a slide of the report asking the chatbot for a "funny limerick about how Microsoft beats Google by integrating ChatGPT into Bing."', 'ChatGPT answered:

"There once was a search engine named Bing

Which was struggling, not doing much thing

But with ChatGPT on its side

It finally got its pride

And left Google searching for its next fling"

Got a tip?', 'Contact the reporter Eugene Kim via the encrypted-messaging apps Signal or Telegram (+1-650-942-3061) or email (ekim@insider.com).', 'Reach out using a nonwork device.', "Check out Insider's source guide for other tips on sharing information securely."]
key_sentences:
The software giant is considered to have a real chance of challenging Google's online search dominance through a partnership with OpenAI and its ChatGPT technology, according to a confidential report prepared recently for Microsoft. Sprinklr, which analyzes online sentiment, studied a wide range of comments about Microsoft, its Bing search engine, ChatGPT, and Google. Many people see "ChatGPT + Bing as a 'threat' or 'challenge' to Google Search," it added. "Bing can leverage the power of ChatGPT for improved results and challenge Google's monopoly," the report, marked Microsoft Confidential, explained. The study ran from late November to early January, capturing data from news publications and online services including Twitter, YouTube, Instagram, and Reddit. They also "enthusiastically" mentioned that ChatGPT's integration with Office applications could "improve efficiency and productivity," while some stated they would "switch to Bing," which could "challenge Google's 'search dominance,'" according to the study. Some said the ChatGPT user experience was "weird" or "scary," and were skeptical of the profitability of investing in an AI research company, like OpenAI, the study found

Still, ChatGPT's "humanlike" responses were seen as a major appeal and an improvement from the current search engine's lists of links, it said. But Microsoft's excitement over its partnership with ChatGPT is best seen in a slide of the report asking the chatbot for a "funny limerick about how Microsoft beats Google by integrating ChatGPT into Bing." ChatGPT answered:

"There once was a search engine named Bing

Which was struggling, not doing much thing

But with ChatGPT on its side

It finally got its pride

And left Google searching for its next fling"

Got a tip?

label: GOOG
title: A bunch of Googlers who used to work at Amazon are internally sharing horror stories about their former employer's 'frupid' and aggressive culture
article:
["For some Amazon employees, joining the company's archrival, Google, can be a shocking revelation and a relief.", 'That's according to more than two dozen Amazonians turned Googlers who shared horror stories about their time at the e-commerce giant, and appreciation for their new employer, in an internal email thread called "worked_at_amazon."', 'Insider reviewed screenshots from this discussion.', 'Followed by almost 2,400 people, the thread is primarily used to connect ex-Amazon employees at Google, but it has become filled with jeers directed at the Seattle company, people on the thread told Insider.', 'These people asked not to be identified talking about sensitive topics.', 'Their identities are known to Insider.', "The discussion — which describes Amazon as a penny-pinching, empathy-lacking corporate behemoth compared with Google's more generous, team-oriented culture — encapsulates striking differences between the two tech giants, at least among some former Amazonians.", '"The culture difference is a complete 180.', 'Amazon is a very kill-or-be-killed environment," one of the people on the email thread told Insider.', '"At Google, we are encouraged to dig and to ask questions.', 'The culture is warm.', 'The leaders listen and want to be helpful."', "Representatives for Amazon and Google didn't respond to requests for comment.", ''Frupidity'

A favorite topic of discussion in recent weeks was Amazon's "frupidity" — a combination of "frugality" and "stupidity."', "While frugality has long been a centerpiece of Amazon's hard-charging culture, these people said the idea had been grossly misused.", 'Insider's recent report about Amazon's "Day 2" culture, which cited frupidity, also brought renewed interest to the issue, people on the email thread told Insider.', 'Frupidity often arose when employees wanted approval for better work devices.', 'One person, who left in 2020, said they had to justify getting an Apple MacBook at work.', "By default, product managers received subpar Windows laptops and weren't eligible for Apple devices, this person wrote.", '"I found it ridiculous because there's no joy in Windows laptops and when there's no joy, no creativity happens and when there's no creativity, what's a PM's worth?"', 'this person wrote in the email thread, likely referring to product managers.', 'Another person, who also left in 2020, said his team used to get only single monitors.', 'To game the system, people would get interns for the summer because those temporary staffers got a monitor, too, and after the internships ended, those extra devices remained.', '(Technically, the monitors had to be returned, but nobody ever did that, this person said.)', '"Pretty frupid to save $200 on something that could increase the productivity of an engineer you were paying six figures to," this person wrote.', 'In some cases, employees had to buddy up with colleagues who oversaw office supplies, this person added.', "His team's policy was to give only one laptop charger per person, for example, but those close to the office-supply manager were able to get a loaner — and not return it until their last day.", "One of the people said Amazon Web Services, which is far more profitable than Amazon's retail business, gave more leeway when it came to expenses.", "On this person's team at AWS, everyone had either two monitors or a huge curved Dell monitor and could generally expense a bunch of other stuff, they added.", '"I wonder if AWS was a little more reasonable and less frupid for small things," this person said.', 'Some people complained up to managers.', 'When Amazon was working on its first iOS app, the team in charge griped about using the "cheapest" MacBooks to do development work and was able to get a slightly better version of the laptops, one person wrote.', 'At Google, every employee, whether they're an engineer or not, is handed a higher-spec MacBook, and those in development work could get a separate "dedicated workstation" as well, this person wrote.', 'Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon.', 'Tony Gutierrez/Associated Press

At Amazon, it could get petty at times.', "Two people on the email thread said cereal boxes were taken away from their office kitchens because they didn't represent a frugal mindset.", 'Another said Amazon used to sell instant-noodle cups for a higher price than the supermarket across the street.', "In one instance, employees at a staff meeting were told to split a bagel between two people because they didn't have the budget to order more beforehand, according to another person.", '"Eventually, we got told, 'Spending a couple hundred bucks on cereal isn't frugal.', 'You are free to solicit donations to try and keep it running,'" one of the people wrote in the email thread.', 'Frupidity has a long history at Amazon, one person wrote.', 'The phrase emerged over 20 years ago when the company decided to remove aspirin and other medications from the mini kitchens to save money, this person wrote in the email thread.', 'Ethan Evans, a former Amazon vice president who spent over 15 years at the company, recently wrote in a blog post that frupidity was the official name of one of the most frequently "degenerate" leadership principles at Amazon.', "How to 'unlearn' Amazon ways

The bigger difference between Google and Amazon, according to these people, is employees' willingness to help each other.", 'One person who recently joined Google, after 15 years at Amazon, said the pace and general helpfulness and respect she's observing at her new job were a "real breath of fresh air."', 'Going to Google from Amazon was a "culture shock," another person wrote, because it's OK to play the new-employee card for the first few months on the job.', '"I have to remind myself that I don't need to have all the answers by the end of my first week, as I was conditioned to do at Amazon," the first person wrote.', 'That also means learning how to "unlearn" the things they picked up while working at Amazon.', 'One person wrote that they were advised by their new Google colleagues to "forget everything about Amazon culture" because it would "not serve you well at Google."', 'Google works better when "we're nice people," one of the people added, saying "the magic sauce for effective teams is empathy."', '"I tend to like everything about Amazon culture better than Google except one thing: how the employees are treated ;)," another person wrote.', 'Do you work at Amazon or Google?', 'Got a tip?', 'Contact reporter Eugene Kim via the encrypted-messaging apps Signal or Telegram (+1-650-942-3061) or email (ekim@insider.com).']
key_sentences:
For some Amazon employees, joining the company's archrival, Google, can be a shocking revelation and a relief. That's according to more than two dozen Amazonians turned Googlers who shared horror stories about their time at the e-commerce giant, and appreciation for their new employer, in an internal email thread called "worked_at_amazon." Followed by almost 2,400 people, the thread is primarily used to connect ex-Amazon employees at Google, but it has become filled with jeers directed at the Seattle company, people on the thread told Insider. The discussion — which describes Amazon as a penny-pinching, empathy-lacking corporate behemoth compared with Google's more generous, team-oriented culture — encapsulates striking differences between the two tech giants, at least among some former Amazonians. "At Google, we are encouraged to dig and to ask questions. Representatives for Amazon and Google didn't respond to requests for comment. At Google, every employee, whether they're an engineer or not, is handed a higher-spec MacBook, and those in development work could get a separate "dedicated workstation" as well, this person wrote. How to 'unlearn' Amazon ways

The bigger difference between Google and Amazon, according to these people, is employees' willingness to help each other. One person who recently joined Google, after 15 years at Amazon, said the pace and general helpfulness and respect she's observing at her new job were a "real breath of fresh air." Going to Google from Amazon was a "culture shock," another person wrote, because it's OK to play the new-employee card for the first few months on the job. One person wrote that they were advised by their new Google colleagues to "forget everything about Amazon culture" because it would "not serve you well at Google." Google works better when "we're nice people," one of the people added, saying "the magic sauce for effective teams is empathy." "I tend to like everything about Amazon culture better than Google except one thing: how the employees are treated ;)," another person wrote. Do you work at Amazon or Google?
